trial_identification.studytitle: A comparison of two versus four sterile water injections for the relief of back pain in labour: A randomised controlled equivalence trial
trial_identification.scientifictitle: For women in labour with back pain does a two sterile water injection technique compared to a four injection result is comparable levels of analgesia

conditions.healthcondition: Women experiencing significant back pain in labour

interventions.interventions: two intradermal injections of 0.1 ml of sterile water over the posterior superior illiac spines. The injection is administered when the woman describes the backpain during any stage of labour, as being equal to or greater than seven on a Visual analogue Scale (VAS). The two injections are administered during a single contraction, by two midwives.
interventions.comparator: Four intradermal injections of 0.1 ml of sterile water to the skin surrounding the Michaelis rhomboid. The injections are administered when the woman describes the backpain during any stage of labour, as being equal to or greater than seven on a Visual analogue Scale (VAS). The four injections are administered during a single contraction, by two midwives.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Decrease in pain measured by Visual Analogue Pain Scale (VAS)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: pain associated with procedure measured by VAS
Pain score of backpain measured by VAS
Pain score of backpain measured by VAS
Pain score of backpain measured by VAS
Pain score of backpain measured by VAS
Patient satisfaction with analgesic effect assesed using Patient Satisfaction Questionnaire
Other analgesia used during labour, data taken from medical records

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Women at term (between 37 and 42 weeks) Nulliparous or multiparous Singleton pregnancy Cephalic presentation First stage labour (spontaneous or induced) No previous analgesia Back pain assessed by VAS as greater than or equal to 7 Ability to give informed consent.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Gestation < 37 weeks Multiple pregnancy Malpresentation (Breech Transverse etc.) Second stage labour Pharmacological analgesia less than 4 hours prior to Sterile Water Injections (SWI) Back pain assessed by VAS < 7 Any medical complications of pregnancy or labour ( type 1 diabetes hypertension requiring intrapartum management).

trial_design.concealment: Participants are invited to enroll in the trial upon experiencing significant back pain in labour. Treatment allocation by numbered sealed opaque envelopes
trial_design.sequence: variable blocks with allocation concealed in numbered, sealed opaque envelope

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Midwifery Research Unit: Australian Catholic University / Mater Research
sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Aubigny Place Mater Health Services South Brisbane Queensland 4101

fundingsource.fundingname: Midwifery Research Unit: Australian Catholic University / Mater Research
fundingsource.fundingaddress: Aubigny Place Mater Health Services South Brisbane Queensland 4101

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The aim of the study is to see if the two sterile water injection technique is as effective as the standard four injection technique in relieving lower back pain during labour and birth. If the difference in pain relief between the two techniques, thirty minutes after injection(s) is no greater or less than 1 centimeter on the VAS, the trial will have proven it's hypothesis
